awd_titl_txt: Interfacial directed assembly and attachment of interconnected nanoparticle networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanoparticles are particles with diameters roughly one thousandth the width of a human hair.  This award supports research to investigate how nanoparticles assemble and attach at the surface of a fluid.  The process is not unlike how some fine powders can form a layer that floats on top of the surface of quiescent water.  Nanoparticle building blocks with programmable size, shape, and composition have become available thanks to recent advances in chemistry. Connecting these building blocks to each other to form "sheets" can give rise to new classes of materials and devices with emergent properties that have intrigued scientists and engineers alike. Unfortunately, assembly instructions are not yet available. This project will close this knowledge gap with a combination of experiments and computer models.  This synergistic approach will unveil key details of the mechanism by which the building blocks self-assemble and attach.   Hence, the results will lead to strategies to design new building blocks that assemble into desirable patterns with minimal defects. This project will produce new knowledge of scientific and societal importance and may lead to the development of new nanostructured materials. Graduate students will receive extensive training in advanced experimental and modeling approaches, and research opportunities will be provided for undergraduates.  Interactive learning modules for local K-12 programs will also be developed.

The combination of self-assembly and directed attachment of colloidal nanoparticles at fluid interfaces presents scientifically interesting and technologically important research challenges. Remarkable strides have been made in the synthesis of polyhedral nanoparticle building blocks with precisely defined shapes and their self-assembly into highly ordered superstructures. Recent advances have revealed intriguing synergies between interfacial self-assembly and directed epitaxial attachment into ordered and connected superstructures. Access to superstructures with programmable symmetry opens new opportunities to create materials with properties by design. The main goal of this work is to attain a better understanding of the basic kinetic and thermodynamic factors governing the interplay of self-assembly and directed-attachment. The investigators hypothesize that the key to predicting and creating coupled assemblies with programmable structures lies in understanding and controlling the nanoparticle orientation at the fluid interface as well as the interactions among particles. The nanoparticle orientation at the liquid-liquid interface and subsequent directed attachment is a complex function of the interfacial energies, the nature of multi-particle interactions and the coupled dynamics of interfacial nanoparticle diffusion, ligand displacement from the nanoparticle surface and epitaxial fusion of adjacent nanoparticles through mutually exposed facets. The mechanism describing how the nanoparticle assembly transforms into an epitaxially connected superstructure presents an interesting unresolved scientific question, and competing hypotheses will be tested via a combination of experiments and simulations. In fact, this provides both a challenge and an opportunity to closely integrate in-situ X-ray structure analysis with multi-scale modeling. The proposal presents a hypothesis-driven collaborative approach with two objectives that aim to understand: (1) how specific nanoparticle superlattice polymorphs assemble at fluid interfaces and (2) how directed attachment can transform the assembled superlattice into an epitaxially connected quasi-2D solid.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Award Title: Interfacial directed assembly and attachment of interconnected nanoparticle networks

Federal Award ID: 1803878

Advances in the synthesis of nanoscale materials has given scientists and engineers access to an expansive library of building blocks with programmable size, shape and composition. Learning how to arrange these building blocks into higher-orders structures is of widespread scientific and technological interest. Inspired by the complexity, beauty and functionality of similar self-assembled structures in nature, significant research efforts, including this project, have pursued the intriguing prospects of tailoring self-assembly processes to create materials whose properties and function can be tuned through the interaction between constituent particles. The overarching vision behind this research endeavor is illustrated in Figure 1.

In ordinary materials, arranging atomic building blocks into ordered structures (i.e., crystals) gives rise to emergent properties that depend on how the building blocks are arranged. For example, arranging carbon atoms into a three-dimensional crystal yields diamond - a very strong, yet insulating material. Alternatively, arranging carbon atoms into planar sheets yields graphite (or single layer graphene) a black, highly conductive material. Guided by these analogies, the overarching objective of this project was to understand and ultimately control how nanomaterial building blocks can be arranged into programmable superstructures. Figure 2 illustrates a key hypothesis of the project which was that understanding and controlling the nanoparticle orientation at the interface and the nature of multi-particle interactions holds the key to directing the formation of nanoparticle assemblies with programmable symmetries.

Assembling the particles at a fluid interface (similar to spreading oil across the surface of water) presents an advantageous experimental testbed to systematically examine the underlying kinetic and thermodynamic conditions governing the assembly. Aside from providing an experimental platform to control the orientation of the colloidal nanoparticle (as shown in Figure 2); the fluid interface also affords the opportunity to perform interfacial  chemical reactions. In the case of the nanoparticle assemblies studied in this project, the researchers took advantage of this feature to examine how to 'connect-the-dots' (i.e., form bonds between particles within the assembly).  

One particularly intriguing aspect of the superstructures at the heart of this project is that the constituent particles not only assemble in specific positions within the lattice, but also form connecting bonds with neighboring particles. The ability to interconnect the particles has important implications on processes such as efficiently transporting electronic signals through the superlattice, yet the mechanism by which these structures from was poorly understood and consequently the quality of the inter-connected superlattices has been inadequate to test theoretically predicted properties.  

The researchers hypothesized that the formation of the connected superlattices involves a choreography of several steps including the initial assembly of the particles, a coordinated reorientation of the particles relative to the fluid surface and ultimately the formation of inter-particle bonds. Connecting the particles is analogous to clicking together LEGO pieces, however the process of interconnecting nanoparticles into a micrometer-scale crystal involves hundreds of thousands of particles whose movement and orientation is coordinated to yield a nearly defect-free crystal-of-crystals. The researchers combined experiment and multi-scale computational simulation to understand the fundamental thermodynamic and kinetic factors governing this assembly and based on that knowledge formulated design principles for the formation of high-fidelity superlattices as summarized in Figure 3.

Key scientific accomplishments of this project include: (1) development of a multi-scale computational model (based on molecular dynamic simulations) to describe the energetically preferred orientation of polyhedral nanoparticles relative to the fluid interface and the mechanism by which the hexagonal assembly is transformed into a square crystal-of-crystals. (see Figure 4) (2) Establishing the foundational relationships between experimental nanoparticle assembly and attachment conditions and the competing concurrent subprocesses of solvent spreading and evaporation, superlattice formation, ligand detachment kinetics, and nanoparticle attachment. The researchers also took advantage of the analogies between 'directed assembly' of constituent nanoparticles and the polymerization of organic monomers to establish a microkinetic model to describe the rate at which nanoparticle 'monomers' form epitaxially connected straight and branched 'oligomers'. Based on these insights we formulated detailed design principles and methodologies for formation of high-fidelity monolayer and multilayer inter-connected superlattices.

Beyond the creation of new knowledge of scientific and technological importance, the project also had important broader societal impact. The graduate students involved in this project received extensive training and experience at the confluence of state-of-the-art experimental and modeling approaches to investigate, understand and predict the formation of new nanostructured materials. To broaden the impact of the project, outreach and education are closely integrated with the scientific work. The investigators worked with local K-12 programs to develope an interactive learning module on 'how things float'.
